content: Barney Frank: TARP's comp curbs could be extended to all businesses Congress will consider legislation to extend some of the curbs on executive pay that now apply only to those banks receiving federal assistance, House Financial Services Committee Chairman Barney Frank said. content: This is really getting to be crap! Politicians (both parties) are jumping on the band wagon depending on which way the wind blows. They are perfectly willing to change their "core values" based on what they perceive to be the popularist view weighed against where they get their campaign financing. Politicians and corporate lawyers...the only professions dedicated solely to self perpetuation!

content: quote: Originally posted by _cash_: quote: Originally posted by Ol_Doc: This is really getting to be crap! Politicians (both parties) are jumping on the band wagon depending on which way the wind blows. They are perfectly willing to change their "core values" based on what they perceive to be the popularist view weighed against where they get their campaign financing. Politicians and corporate lawyers...the only professions dedicated to self perpetuation! Good take! And some of the rest of us just want to pick up the pieces and move forward......but not socialism.....so much! True, we have to find the middle ground. Socialism is no more viable than uncontrolled capitalism IMHO. We need to identify the necessary "commons" and pay for them, but I'm not ready to cross the line to "state run economy".

content: quote: Originally posted by shuman14: WHY do people keep voting for this guy? This guy is a POS, he is the same person who protected mae/mac and now he is pulling self righteous crap in another cya move. I think congress should get a pay cut buy this. This freakin thing drips with hypocrisy! quote: "Pay for Performance Act of 2009" The purpose of the legislation is to "prohibit unreasonable and excessive compensation and compensation not based on performance standards," according to the bill's language. That includes regular pay, bonuses -- everything -- paid to employees of companies in whom the government has a capital stake, including those that have received funds through the Troubled Assets Relief Program, or TARP, as well as Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. quote: "Rep. Alan Grayson, the Florida Democrat who wrote the bill, told me its basic message is "you should not get rich off public money, and you should not get rich off of abject failure" LMAO! How many in this Adm and in congress got money from MAE/MAC. Thats all these guys do is profit from public money

content: quote: Originally posted by GunnyRet03: quote: Originally posted by shuman14: WHY do people keep voting for this guy? This guy is a POS, he is the same person who protected mae/mac and now he is pulling self righteous crap in another cya move. I think congress should get a pay cut buy this. This freakin thing drips with hypocrisy! quote: "Pay for Performance Act of 2009" The purpose of the legislation is to "prohibit unreasonable and excessive compensation and compensation not based on performance standards," according to the bill's language. That includes regular pay, bonuses -- everything -- paid to employees of companies in whom the government has a capital stake, including those that have received funds through the Troubled Assets Relief Program, or TARP, as well as Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. I disagree! If they don't take TARP money we have nothing to say about their compensation. If they do take the money...we own their azzes and their management can dance to our tune until they repay the American taxpayers.
quote: Originally posted by GunnyRet03: quote: Originally posted by shuman14: WHY do people keep voting for this guy? This guy is a POS, he is the same person who protected mae/mac and now he is pulling self righteous crap in another cya move. I think congress should get a pay cut buy this. That includes regular pay, bonuses -- everything -- paid to employees of companies in whom the government has a capital stake, including those that have received funds through the Troubled Assets Relief Program, or TARP, as well as Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.
reply: I disagree! If they don't take TARP money we have nothing to say about their compensation. If they do take the money...we own their azzes and their management can dance to our tune until they repay the American taxpayers.

content: Ol' Doc, so in your opinion, every school taking public funsding needs to subject its' payscale to the government? Some get 6 figures, you know, and don't teach. Some Administrators get paid mid 6 figures and more AND need "begathons" to just break even. And DEFENSE CONTRACTORS all get paid with Fed. Funds, so naturally, the government should manage them too? And those contractors that build highway systems, why, their money is TAX MONEY, so we should decide what everyone from the CEO to the flag waver at a worksite earn? And ALL BANKS that are FDIC insured of use the Fwed. Funds. overnight funds loans also use fed. money , so we should controle these companies too, and the suppliers, and the asphaslt plants, cement plants, tire manufacturers, etc etc etc? Tell me, it would be a shorter list, who ashould NOT have their livelyhood directed by Barney Frank and Mr. Obama?

content: quote: Originally posted by Ol_Doc: quote: Originally posted by LineDoggie: Barney Frank: TARP's comp curbs could be extended to all businesses Congress will consider legislation to extend some of the curbs on executive pay that now apply only to those banks receiving federal assistance, House Financial Services Committee Chairman Barney Frank said. He said the compensation restrictions would apply to all financial institutions and might be extended to include all U.S. companies. XXXhttp://www.financialweek.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20090203/REG/902039977/1003/TOCXXX Is it Socialism Yet? I can hear his lispy voice now "Mr. Jones, are you now , or have you ever been, a Capitalist?" People in hell want icewater. It's not going to happen unless business decide on their own to bend to public opinion. Barny Franks can "want" anything he would like...wish in one hand... Unlike some normal crackpot Frank happens to be an elected official that can introduce legislation. He has political power to do it and whether or not it would pass depends on other elected officials. Brushing off an assault on Capitalism by Mr. Frank (an elected official in Congress) by playing it off as not a big deal is kinda lame don't you think?
